<!--[if lt IE 7]><style type="text/css">body{behavior:url("/w/skins/vector/csshover.min.htc")}</style><![endif]--></head>
<body class="mediawiki ltr sitedir-ltr ns-0 ns-subject page-Gelatin skin-vector action-view vector-animateLayout">
		<div id="mw-page-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="mw-head-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="content" class="mw-body" role="main">
			<a id="top"></a>
			<div id="mw-js-message" style="display:none;"></div>
						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">Gelatin</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-navigation">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
				</div>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><div class="dablink">For this dessert food, see <a href="/wiki/Gelatin_dessert" title="Gelatin dessert">Gelatin dessert</a>.</div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Gelatine.png" title="File:Gelatine.png">File:Gelatine.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">'Sheet' or 'leaf' gelatin for cooking</div></div></div>
<p><b>Gelatin</b> or <b>gelatine</b> (from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Lang-la&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Lang-la (page does not exist)">Template:Lang-la</a> meaning "stiff", "frozen") is a translucent, colorless, brittle (when dry),  flavorless <a href="/w/index.php?title=Solid&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Solid (page does not exist)">solid substance</a>, derived from  <a href="/wiki/Collagen" title="Collagen">collagen</a> obtained from various animal by-products. It is commonly used as a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gelling_agent&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gelling agent (page does not exist)">gelling agent</a> in <a href="/wiki/Food" title="Food">food</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pharmaceuticals" title="Pharmaceuticals" class="mw-redirect">pharmaceuticals</a>, <a href="/wiki/Photography" title="Photography">photography</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cosmetic_manufacturing&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cosmetic manufacturing (page does not exist)">cosmetic manufacturing</a>. Substances containing gelatin or functioning in a similar way are called <i>gelatinous</i>. Gelatin is an irreversibly <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hydrolysed&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hydrolysed (page does not exist)">hydrolysed</a> form of collagen, and is classified as a foodstuff.  It is found in most <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gummy_candies&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gummy candies (page does not exist)">gummy candies</a> as well as other products such as <a href="/wiki/Marshmallows" title="Marshmallows" class="mw-redirect">marshmallows</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gelatin_dessert" title="Gelatin dessert">gelatin dessert</a>, and some <a href="/wiki/Ice_cream" title="Ice cream">ice cream</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dip_(food)" title="Dip (food)">dip</a> and <a href="/wiki/Yogurt" title="Yogurt">yogurt</a>. Household gelatin comes in the form of sheets, granules, or powder. Instant types can be added to the food as they are; others need to be soaked in water beforehand. Gelatin has <a href="/wiki/E_number" title="E number">E number</a> E441.
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc"><div id="toctitle"><h2>Contents</h2></div>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Composition_and_properties"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Composition and properties</span></a></li>

<ul>

<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-4"><a href="#Extraction"><span class="tocnumber">2.2</span> <span class="toctext">Extraction</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-5"><a href="#Recovery"><span class="tocnumber">2.3</span> <span class="toctext">Recovery</span></a></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-6"><a href="#Uses"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">Uses</span></a>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-7"><a href="#Technical_uses"><span class="tocnumber">3.1</span> <span class="toctext">Technical uses</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-8"><a href="#Other_uses"><span class="tocnumber">3.2</span> <span class="toctext">Other uses</span></a></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-9"><a href="#Dietary_restrictions_and_gelatin_substitutes"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">Dietary restrictions and gelatin substitutes</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-10"><a href="#Medical_and_nutritional_properties"><span class="tocnumber">5</span> <span class="toctext">Medical and nutritional properties</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-11"><a href="#Safety_concerns"><span class="tocnumber">6</span> <span class="toctext">Safety concerns</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-12"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">7</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Composition_and_properties">Composition and properties</span></h2>
<p>Gelatin is a mixture of <a href="/wiki/Peptide" title="Peptide">peptides</a> and <a href="/wiki/Protein" title="Protein">proteins</a> produced by partial <a href="/wiki/Hydrolysis" title="Hydrolysis">hydrolysis</a> of <a href="/wiki/Collagen" title="Collagen">collagen</a> extracted from the skin, bones, and connective tissues of animals such as domesticated <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cattle&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cattle (page does not exist)">cattle</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chicken" title="Chicken">chicken</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pig" title="Pig">pigs</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fish&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fish (page does not exist)">fish</a>. Photographic and pharma grades of gelatin are generally made from beef bones, although some beef bone gelatin is used by the food industry. Gelatin is an animal protein unlike many other gelling agents used by the food industry.
</p><p>The natural molecular bonds between individual collagen strands are broken down into a form that rearranges more easily. Gelatin melts to a liquid when heated and solidifies when cooled again. Together with water, it forms a semi-solid <a href="/wiki/Gel" title="Gel">gel</a>.  
Gelatin forms a solution of high <a href="/w/index.php?title=Viscosity&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Viscosity (page does not exist)">viscosity</a> in water, which sets to a gel on cooling, and its chemical composition is, in many respects, closely similar to that of its parent collagen.<sup id="cite_ref-Ward_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ward-1">[1]</a></sup>  Gelatin is also soluble in most <a href="/wiki/Solvent" title="Solvent">polar solvents</a>. 
</p><p>Gelatin solutions show viscoelastic flow and streaming <a href="/wiki/Birefringence" title="Birefringence">birefringence</a>. If gelatin is put into contact with cold water, some of the material dissolves, but not all. The solubility of the gelatin is determined by the method of manufacture. Typically, gelatin can be dispersed in a relatively concentrated acid. Such dispersions are stable for 10–15 days with little or no chemical changes and are suitable for coating purposes or for extrusion into a precipitating bath. 
</p><p>Gelatin gels exist over only a small temperature range, the upper limit being the melting point of the gel, which depends on gelatin grade and concentration (but is typically less than 35&#160;°C) and the lower limit the freezing point at which ice crystallizes. The upper melting point is below <a href="/w/index.php?title=Human_body_temperature&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Human body temperature (page does not exist)">human body temperature</a>, a factor which is important for <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mouthfeel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mouthfeel (page does not exist)">mouthfeel</a> of foods produced with gelatin.<sup id="cite_ref-Cole_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cole-2">[2]</a></sup>
</p><p>Mechanical properties of gelatin gels (for example the gel strength, which is quantified using the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bloom_(test)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bloom (test) (page does not exist)">Bloom test</a>) are very sensitive to temperature variations, previous thermal history of the gel, and time. The viscosity of the gelatin/water mixture increases with concentration and when kept cool (≈ 4 °C).
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Production">Production</span></h2>
<div class="floatright"><a href="/wiki/File:Materials_Used_in_Gelatin_Production.svg" title="File:Materials Used in Gelatin Production.svg">File:Materials Used in Gelatin Production.svg</a></div>
<div class="floatright"><a href="/wiki/File:Gelatin_Production_by_Geography.svg" title="File:Gelatin Production by Geography.svg">File:Gelatin Production by Geography.svg</a></div>
<p>The worldwide production amount of gelatin is about 375,000 tons per year (roughly 827 million lb).{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} On a commercial scale, gelatin is made from <a href="/wiki/By-product" title="By-product">by-products</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Meat" title="Meat">meat</a> and <a href="/wiki/Leather" title="Leather">leather</a> industry. Recently, fish by-products have also been considered because they eliminate some of the religious obstacles surrounding gelatin consumption.<sup id="cite_ref-Cole_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cole-2">[2]</a></sup>
Gelatin is derived from pork skins, pork, horses, and cattle bones, or split cattle hides.<sup id="cite_ref-gmia_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gmia-3">[3]</a></sup> The raw materials are prepared by different curing, acid, and alkali processes which are employed to extract the dried collagen hydrolysate. These processes<sup id="cite_ref-Rousselot_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rousselot-4">[4]</a></sup> may take up to several weeks, and differences in such processes have great effects on the properties of the final gelatin products.<sup id="cite_ref-gelita_5-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gelita-5">[5]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gelatin can also be prepared in the home. Boiling certain cartilaginous cuts of meat or bones will result in gelatin being dissolved into the water. Depending on the concentration, the resulting stock (when cooled) will naturally form a <a href="/wiki/Gelatin_dessert" title="Gelatin dessert">jelly</a> or gel. This process is used for <a href="/wiki/Aspic" title="Aspic">aspic</a>.
</p><p>While there are many processes whereby collagen can be converted to gelatin, they all have several factors in common. The intermolecular and intramolecular bonds which stabilize insoluble collagen rendering it insoluble must be broken, and the hydrogen bonds which stabilize the collagen <a href="/wiki/Helix" title="Helix">helix</a> must also be broken.<sup id="cite_ref-Ward_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ward-1">[1]</a></sup> The manufacturing processes of gelatin consists of three main stages:
</p>
<ol>
<li>Pretreatments to make the raw materials ready for the main extraction step and to remove impurities which may have negative effects on physio chemical properties of the final gelatin product,
</li>
<li>The main extraction step, which is usually done with hot water or dilute acid solutions as a multi-stage extraction to hydrolyze collagen into gelatin, and finally,
</li>
<li>The refining and recovering treatments including filtration, clarification, evaporation, sterilization, drying, rutting, grinding, and sifting to remove the water from the gelatin solution, to blend the gelatin extracted, and to obtain dried, blended and ground final product.
</li>
</ol>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Pretreatments">Pretreatments</span></h3>
<p>{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Unreferenced section |date=__DATE__ |$B=
{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Unreferenced |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Ambox&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Ambox (page does not exist)">Template:Ambox</a>
}}
}}
If the raw material used in the production of the gelatin is derived from <a href="/wiki/Bone" title="Bone">bones</a>, dilute <a href="/wiki/Acid" title="Acid">acid</a> solutions are used to remove <a href="/wiki/Calcium" title="Calcium">calcium</a> and other salts. Hot water or several solvents may be used in order to reduce the fat content, which should not exceed 1% before the main extraction step. If the raw material consists of <a href="/wiki/Hide_(skin)" title="Hide (skin)">hides</a> and <a href="/wiki/Skin" title="Skin">skin</a>, size reduction, washing, removal of hair from hides and de-greasing are necessary to prepare the hides and skins for the main extraction step.
</p><p>Collagen hydrolysis is performed by one of three different methods: <a href="/w/index.php?title=Acid_hydrolysis&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Acid hydrolysis (page does not exist)">acid</a>-, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Base_hydrolysis&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Base hydrolysis (page does not exist)">alkali</a>-, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Enzymatic_hydrolysis&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Enzymatic hydrolysis (page does not exist)">enzymatic hydrolysis</a>. Acid treatment is especially suitable for less fully <a href="/w/index.php?title=Crosslink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Crosslink (page does not exist)">crosslinked</a> materials such as pig skin collagen and normally requires 10 to 48 hours. Alkali treatment is suitable for more complex collagen such as the collagen found in <a href="/wiki/Bovine" title="Bovine" class="mw-redirect">bovine</a> hides and requires more time, normally several weeks. The purpose of the alkali treatment is to destroy certain chemical crosslinkages still present in collagen. The gelatin obtained from acid-treated raw material has been called type-A gelatin and the gelatin obtained from alkali-treated raw material is referred to as type-B gelatin. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:By_whom&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:By whom (page does not exist)">Template:By whom</a>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Enzymatic_hydrolysis&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Enzymatic hydrolysis (page does not exist)">Enzymatic hydrolysis</a> of collagen for gelatin extraction is relatively new. However, the treatment time is shorter than that required for alkali treatment, and results in almost complete conversion to the pure product. The physical properties of the final gelatin product are better. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Whom&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Whom (page does not exist)">Template:Whom</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Extraction">Extraction</span></h3>
<p>After preparation of the raw cool material, i.e., reducing crosslinkages between collagen components and removing some of the impurities such as fat and salts, partially purified collagen is converted into gelatin by extraction with either water or acid solutions at appropriate temperatures. All industrial processes are based on neutral or acid pH values because though alkali treatments speed up conversion, they also promote degradation processes. Acid extract conditions are extensively used in the industry but the degree of acid varies with different processes. This extraction step is a multi stage process, and the extraction temperature is usually increased in later extraction steps. This procedure ensures the minimum thermal degradation of the extracted gelatin.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Recovery">Recovery</span></h3>
<p>This process includes several steps such as filtration, evaporation, drying, grinding, and sifting. These operations are concentration-dependent and also dependent on the particular gelatin used. Gelatin degradation should be avoided and minimized, therefore the lowest temperature possible is used for the recovery process. Most recoveries are rapid, with all of the processes being done in several stages to avoid extensive deterioration of the peptide structure. A deteriorated peptide structure would result in a low gelling strength, which is not generally desired.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Uses">Uses</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Oeufs_en_gel%C3%A9e_p1150406.jpg" title="File:Oeufs en gelée p1150406.jpg">File:Oeufs en gelée p1150406.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Egg_(food)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Egg (food) (page does not exist)">Eggs</a> in <a href="/wiki/Aspic" title="Aspic">aspic</a></div></div></div>
<p>Probably best known as a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gelling_agent&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gelling agent (page does not exist)">gelling agent</a> in <a href="/wiki/Cooking" title="Cooking">cooking</a>, different types and grades of gelatin are used in a wide range of food and non-food products:
Common examples of foods that contain gelatin are <a href="/wiki/Gelatin_dessert" title="Gelatin dessert">gelatin desserts</a>, <a href="/wiki/Trifle" title="Trifle">trifles</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aspic" title="Aspic">aspic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Marshmallow" title="Marshmallow">marshmallows</a>, <a href="/wiki/Candy_corn" title="Candy corn">candy corn</a>, and confections such as <a href="/wiki/Peeps" title="Peeps">Peeps</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gummy_bear" title="Gummy bear">gummy bears</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fruit_snack&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fruit snack (page does not exist)">fruit snacks</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jelly_baby&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jelly baby (page does not exist)">jelly babies</a>. Gelatin may be used as a <a href="/wiki/Food_additive#Categories" title="Food additive">stabilizer</a>, thickener, or texturizer in foods such as <a href="/wiki/Yogurt" title="Yogurt">yogurt</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cream_cheese" title="Cream cheese">cream cheese</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Margarine" title="Margarine">margarine</a>; it is used, as well, in fat-reduced foods to simulate the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mouthfeel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mouthfeel (page does not exist)">mouthfeel</a> of fat and to create volume without adding calories.
</p><p>Gelatin is used for the clarification of juices, such as apple juice, and of vinegar. <a href="/wiki/Isinglass" title="Isinglass">Isinglass</a>, from the swim bladders of fish, is still used as a fining agent for wine and beer.<sup id="cite_ref-omri_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-omri-6">[6]</a></sup> Beside <a href="/wiki/Hartshorn" title="Hartshorn">hartshorn</a> jelly, from deer antlers (hence the name "hartshorn"), isinglass was one of the oldest sources of gelatin.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Technical_uses">Technical uses</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Kapsel_beredningsform.jpg" title="File:Kapsel beredningsform.jpg">File:Kapsel beredningsform.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Capsules made of gelatin.</div></div></div>
<ul>
<li> Certain professional and theatrical lighting equipment use <a href="/wiki/Color_gel" title="Color gel">color gels</a> to change the <a href="/wiki/Light_beam" title="Light beam">beam</a> color. These were historically made with gelatin, hence the term color gel.
</li>
<li> Gelatin typically constitutes the shells of pharmaceutical <a href="/w/index.php?title=Capsule_(pharmacy)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Capsule (pharmacy) (page does not exist)">capsules</a> in order to make them easier to swallow. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hypromellose&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hypromellose (page does not exist)">Hypromellose</a> is a vegetarian-acceptable alternative to gelatin, but is more expensive to produce.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
</li>
</ul>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}
</p>
<ul>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Animal_glue&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Animal glue (page does not exist)">Animal glues</a> such as hide glue are essentially unrefined gelatin.
</li>
<li> It is used to hold <a href="/wiki/Silver_halide" title="Silver halide">silver halide</a> crystals in an <a href="/wiki/Emulsion" title="Emulsion">emulsion</a> in virtually all <a href="/w/index.php?title=Photographic_film&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Photographic film (page does not exist)">photographic films</a> and <a href="/wiki/Photographic_paper" title="Photographic paper">photographic papers</a>. Despite some efforts, no suitable substitutes with the stability and low cost of gelatin have been found.
</li>
<li> Used as a carrier, coating or separating agent for other substances; for example, it makes <a href="/w/index.php?title=Beta-carotene&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Beta-carotene (page does not exist)">beta-carotene</a> water-soluble thus imparting a yellow colour to any <a href="/wiki/Soft_drink" title="Soft drink">soft drinks</a> containing beta-carotene.
</li>
<li> Gelatin is closely related to bone glue and is used as a binder in <a href="/wiki/Match" title="Match">match</a> heads and <a href="/wiki/Sandpaper" title="Sandpaper">sandpaper</a>.
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Cosmetics" title="Cosmetics">Cosmetics</a> may contain a non-gelling variant of gelatin under the name <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hydrolyzed_collagen_(hydrolysate)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hydrolyzed collagen (hydrolysate) (page does not exist)">hydrolyzed collagen</a>.
</li>
<li> Gelatin was first used as an external surface <a href="/wiki/Sizing" title="Sizing">sizing</a> for paper in 1337 and continued as a dominant sizing agent of all European papers through the mid-19th century.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">[7]</a></sup> In modern times it occasionally found in some glossy printing papers, artistic papers, playing cards, and it maintains the wrinkles in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cr%C3%AApe_paper&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Crêpe paper (page does not exist)">crêpe paper</a>.
</li>
</ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Other_uses">Other uses</span></h3>
<ul>
<li> Blocks of <a href="/wiki/Ballistic_gelatin" title="Ballistic gelatin">ballistic gelatin</a> simulate muscle tissue as a standardized medium for testing <a href="/wiki/Firearm" title="Firearm">firearms</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ammunition&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ammunition (page does not exist)">ammunition</a>.
</li>
<li> Gelatin is used by <a href="/wiki/Synchronized_swimming" title="Synchronized swimming">synchronized swimmers</a> to hold their hair in place during their routines as it will not dissolve in the cold water of the pool. It is frequently referred to as "knoxing," a reference to Knox brand gelatin.<sup id="cite_ref-synchro_8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-synchro-8">[8]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> When added to boiling water and cooled, unflavored gelatin can make a home-made <a href="/wiki/Hair_gel" title="Hair gel">hair styling gel</a> that is cheaper than many commercial hair styling products, but by comparison has a shorter shelf life (about a week) when stored in this form (usually in a refrigerator). After being applied to scalp hair, it can be removed with rinsing and some shampoo.
</li>
<li> It is commonly used as a biological substrate to culture adherent cells.
</li>
<li> Also used by those who are sensitive to tannins (which can irritate the stomach) in teas, soups or brews.
</li>
<li> It may be used as a medium with which to consume <a href="/w/index.php?title=LSD&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="LSD (page does not exist)">LSD</a>. LSD in gelatin form is known as "windowpane" or "geltabs."
</li>
<li> Gelatin is used to make the shells of <a href="/wiki/Paintballs" title="Paintballs" class="mw-redirect">paintballs</a>, similar to the way pharmaceutical capsules are produced.
</li>
<li> Gelatin is also used as an ingredient in implantable medical devices, such as in some bone void fillers. 
</li>
<li> Gelatin is also used in nail polish remover and makeup applications. The gelatin is often tinted in different colors to match a model's natural skin tone.
</li>
<li> Leaf or sheet gelatin is also used directly in food-based model-making, for example to make translucent, edible, diamond-paned windows in <a href="/wiki/Gingerbread_house" title="Gingerbread house">gingerbread houses</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">[9]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> Gelatin can be used as a binding agent in <a href="/w/index.php?title=India_ink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="India ink (page does not exist)">india ink</a>.
</li>
</ul>
<ul>
<li> Gelatin may additionally be used as a technique within the process of fine art <a href="/wiki/Printmaking" title="Printmaking">printmaking</a>. The prints are made  by creating a block of gelatin and applying printing inks.  The gelatin is made using twice the normal amount of gelatin granules to the usual amount of water.  Once set - printmaking ink (usually water based) is applied to its surface.  Other water based media may also be applied.   Items such as dried grass,  leaves and paper stencils are placed onto the inked surface.  Gelatin <a href="/wiki/Monotype" title="Monotype" class="mw-redirect">monotype</a> is best done with the use of medium to lightweight paper.  This is  gently pressed onto the inked plate once the 'design' has been composed.
</li>
</ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Dietary_restrictions_and_gelatin_substitutes">Dietary restrictions and gelatin substitutes</span></h2>
<p>Special kinds of gelatin indicate the specific animal that was used for its production. The consumption of gelatin from particular animals may be forbidden by religious or cultural rules. For example, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jew&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jew (page does not exist)">Jewish</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kosher&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kosher (page does not exist)">kosher</a> customs require gelatin from sources other than pigs, like cows and/or fish and from animals slaughtered ritually.<a href="/wiki/Romani_people" title="Romani people">Romani people</a> are cautious of gelatin products that may have been made from horses, as their culture forbids the consumption of horses. There are many companies that specify the source of the gelatin used, and advise consumers via the nutrition information and/or their hotline.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vegan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vegan (page does not exist)">Vegans</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vegetarian" title="Vegetarian" class="mw-redirect">vegetarians</a> choose not to eat foods containing gelatin made from animals. Likewise, <a href="/wiki/Hindu" title="Hindu">Hindu</a> &amp; <a href="/wiki/Jain" title="Jain" class="mw-redirect">Jain</a> customs may require gelatin alternatives from sources other than animals, as many Hindus are vegetarian. Hindus who are not vegetarians will often consume gelatin from all sources except cow, which is considered sacred. Other people simply consider gelatin unpalatable due to the ingredients used in its production. Partial, non-animal alternatives to gelatin include the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Seaweed&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Seaweed (page does not exist)">seaweed</a> extracts <a href="/wiki/Agar" title="Agar">agar</a> and <a href="/wiki/Carrageenan" title="Carrageenan">carrageenan</a>, as well as <a href="/wiki/Pectin" title="Pectin">pectin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Konjak" title="Konjak" class="mw-redirect">konjak</a>. Research into synthetic collagen is ongoing, as of 2011 partial success has been achieved in replicating collagen's structure using self-assembling peptides.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Medical_and_nutritional_properties">Medical and nutritional properties</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Amino_Acid_Composition_in_Gelatin_chart.png" title="File:Amino Acid Composition in Gelatin chart.png">File:Amino Acid Composition in Gelatin chart.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Amino_acid" title="Amino acid">Amino acid</a> composition</div></div></div>
<p>Although gelatin is 98-99% protein by dry weight, it has less nutritional value than many other <a href="/w/index.php?title=Complete_protein&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Complete protein (page does not exist)">complete protein</a> sources. Gelatin is unusually high in the non-essential <a href="/wiki/Amino_acid" title="Amino acid">amino acids</a> <a href="/wiki/Glycine" title="Glycine">glycine</a> and <a href="/wiki/Proline" title="Proline">proline</a> (i.e., those produced by the human body), while lacking certain <a href="/wiki/Essential_amino_acid" title="Essential amino acid">essential amino acids</a> (i.e., those not produced by the human body). It contains no <a href="/wiki/Tryptophan" title="Tryptophan">tryptophan</a> and is deficient in <a href="/wiki/Isoleucine" title="Isoleucine">isoleucine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Threonine" title="Threonine">threonine</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Methionine" title="Methionine">methionine</a>. The approximate amino acid composition of gelatin is: <a href="/wiki/Glycine" title="Glycine">glycine</a> 21%, <a href="/wiki/Proline" title="Proline">proline</a> 12%, <a href="/wiki/Hydroxyproline" title="Hydroxyproline">hydroxyproline</a> 12%, <a href="/wiki/Glutamic_acid" title="Glutamic acid">glutamic acid</a> 10%, <a href="/wiki/Alanine" title="Alanine">alanine</a> 9%, <a href="/wiki/Arginine" title="Arginine">arginine</a> 8%, <a href="/wiki/Aspartic_acid" title="Aspartic acid">aspartic acid</a> 6%, <a href="/wiki/Lysine" title="Lysine">lysine</a> 4%, <a href="/wiki/Serine" title="Serine">serine</a> 4%, <a href="/wiki/Leucine" title="Leucine">leucine</a> 3%, <a href="/wiki/Valine" title="Valine">valine</a> 2%, <a href="/wiki/Phenylalanine" title="Phenylalanine">phenylalanine</a> 2%, <a href="/wiki/Threonine" title="Threonine">threonine</a> 2%, <a href="/wiki/Isoleucine" title="Isoleucine">isoleucine</a> 1%, <a href="/wiki/Hydroxylysine" title="Hydroxylysine">hydroxylysine</a> 1%, <a href="/wiki/Methionine" title="Methionine">methionine</a> and <a href="/wiki/Histidine" title="Histidine">histidine</a> &lt;1% and <a href="/wiki/Tyrosine" title="Tyrosine">tyrosine</a> &lt;0.5%. These values vary, especially the minor constituents, depending on the source of the raw material and processing technique.<sup id="cite_ref-stevens_11-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-stevens-11">[11]</a></sup>
</p><p>Short chain gelatin peptides are effective in the treatment of <a href="/wiki/Stomach_ulcer" title="Stomach ulcer" class="mw-redirect">stomach ulcers</a>. The peptides enhance resistance of the <a href="/wiki/Mucous_membrane" title="Mucous membrane">mucous membrane</a> to <a href="/wiki/Ethanol" title="Ethanol">ethanol</a> and the effects of stress, causing a twofold reduction in ulcer size and faster healing.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">[12]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gelatin is also a topical <a href="/w/index.php?title=Haemostatic&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Haemostatic (page does not exist)">haemostatic</a>. A piece of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Absorbable_gelatin_sponge&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Absorbable gelatin sponge (page does not exist)">gelatin sponge</a> of appropriate size is applied on bleeding wound, pressed for some time and tied in bandage. Haemostatic action is based on platelets damage at the contact of blood with gelatin, which activates the coagulation cascade. Gelatin also causes a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tamponading_effect&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tamponading effect (page does not exist)">tamponading effect</a> - blood flow stoppage into a blood vessel by a constriction of the vessel by an outside force.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Page_needed&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Page needed (page does not exist)">Template:Page needed</a>
</p><p>Gelatin has also been claimed to promote general joint health. A study at <a href="/wiki/Ball_State_University" title="Ball State University">Ball State University</a> sponsored by <a href="/wiki/Nabisco" title="Nabisco">Nabisco</a>, the former parent company of Knox gelatin,<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Clarification_needed&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Clarification needed (page does not exist)">Template:Clarification needed</a>   
</p><p>It has been claimed that oral gelatin consumption has a beneficial therapeutic effect on hair loss in both men and women.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[15]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup>In addition there are scientific publications that present evidence that consumption of oral gelatin has beneficial effect for some fingernail changes and diseases.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Safety_concerns">Safety concerns</span></h2>
<p>Strict regulations apply for all steps in the gelatin manufacturing process. Gelatin is produced from natural raw materials which originate from animals that have been examined and accepted for human consumption by veterinary authorities. Hygienic regulations with respect to fresh raw materials are ensured and each batch of raw material delivered to the manufacturing plant is immediately checked and documented. {{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}
</p><p>In addition to the raw material quality, also the production process itself is an effective quality assurance measure. In the production process a comprehensive monitoring system ensures that potential risks are minimized. {{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}
</p><p>The U.S. <a href="/wiki/Food_and_Drug_Administration" title="Food and Drug Administration">Food and Drug Administration</a> (FDA), with support from the TSE (<a href="/wiki/Transmissible_spongiform_encephalopathy" title="Transmissible spongiform encephalopathy">Transmissible spongiform encephalopathy</a>) Advisory Committee, has since 1997 been monitoring the potential risk of transmitting animal diseases, especially <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bovine_spongiform_encephalopathy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bovine spongiform encephalopathy (page does not exist)">bovine spongiform encephalopathy</a> (BSE), commonly known as Mad Cow disease. The FDA study concluded:  "...steps such as heat, alkaline treatment, and filtration could be effective in reducing the level of contaminating TSE agents; however, scientific evidence is insufficient at this time to demonstrate that these treatments would effectively remove the BSE infectious agent if present in the source material."<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Scientific Steering Committee (SSC) of the European Union (EU) in 2003 stated that the risk associated with bovine bone gelatin is very low or zero.<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup>
In 2006 the <a href="/w/index.php?title=European_Food_Safety_Authority&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="European Food Safety Authority (page does not exist)">European Food Safety Authority</a> (EFSA) stated that the SSC opinion was confirmed, that the BSE risk of bone-derived gelatin was very small, and removed support for the 2003 request of excluding the skull and vertebrae of bovine origin older than 12 months from the material used in gelatin manufacturing.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[34]</a></sup>
</p><p>All reputable gelatin manufacturers today follow the Quality Management System according to <a href="/wiki/ISO_9001" title="ISO 9001" class="mw-redirect">ISO 9001</a> to comply with all required physical, chemical, microbiological and technical production and quality standards. In this way all process steps follow international laws and customer-specific quality parameters and are guaranteed and documented. For pharmaceutical grade gelatins strict regulations from the Food and Drug Administration (FDA), the European CPMP's regulation and European Pharmacopoeia must be met. A detailed overview of the regulatory requirements for gelatin production can be found in the <i>Gelatine Handbook</i>, pp. 99–101.<sup id="cite_ref-isbn3-527-31548-9_35-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-isbn3-527-31548-9-35">[35]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Reflist&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Reflist (page does not exist)">Template:Reflist</a>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sister&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sister (page does not exist)">Template:Sister</a>
<br /><strong class="error mw-ext-cite-error">Cite error: <code>&lt;ref&gt;</code> tags exist, but no <code>&lt;references/&gt;</code> tag was found</strong>
</p>
<!--

-->

	<form action="/w/index.php" id="searchform">

				<div class="portal" role="navigation" id='p-navigation' aria-labelledby='p-navigation-label'>
	<h3 id='p-navigation-label'>Navigation</h3>
	<div class="body">
		<ul>
			<li id="n-mainpage-description"><a href="/wiki/Main_Page" title="Visit the main page [z]" accesskey="z">Main page</a></li>
			<li id="n-contents"><a href="/wiki/Portal:Contents">contents</a></li>
			<li id="n-featuredcontent"><a href="/wiki/Portal:Featured_content">featuredcontent</a></li>
			<li id="n-currentevents"><a href="/wiki/Portal:Current_events" title="Find background information on current events">Current events</a></li>
			<li id="n-randompage"><a href="/wiki/Special:Random" title="Load a random page [x]" accesskey="x">Random article</a></li>
			<li id="n-sitesupport"><a href="https://donate.wikimedia.org/wiki/Special:FundraiserRedirector?utm_source=donate&amp;utm_medium=sidebar&amp;utm_campaign=C13_en.wikipedia.org&amp;uselang=en" rel="nofollow">Donate to Wikipedia</a></li>
		</ul>
	</div>
</div>
